name: Photosynthesis Model
description: A simplified model showing how plants convert sunlight, water, and carbon dioxide into glucose and oxygen. This model demonstrates the light-dependent and light-independent reactions of photosynthesis.
learningObjectives: Understand the inputs and outputs of photosynthesis
Learn how sunlight drives the photosynthesis process
Observe how different components activate and inhibit each other
See the cyclical nature of biological processes

components.name: Sunlight
components.description: Light energy from the sun that drives photosynthesis

components.name: Carbon Dioxide
components.description: CO₂ absorbed from the air through stomata

components.name: Chlorophyll
components.description: Green pigment that captures light energy

components.name: Light Reactions
components.description: Process that converts light energy to chemical energy (ATP and NADPH)

components.name: Calvin Cycle
components.description: Process that uses ATP and NADPH to convert CO₂ into glucose

components.name: Glucose (C₆H₁₂O₆)
components.description: Sugar produced by photosynthesis - plant food!

components.name: Oxygen (O₂)
components.description: Byproduct of photosynthesis released into the air

connections.description: Water is split during light reactions
Light reactions release oxygen as a byproduct
ATP provides energy for the Calvin Cycle
NADPH provides electrons for the Calvin Cycle
CO₂ is fixed in the Calvin Cycle

instructions: This model shows the two main stages of photosynthesis:
1. Light Reactions: Sunlight → ATP + NADPH + O₂
2. Calvin Cycle: ATP + NADPH + CO₂ → Glucose
• Run the simulation with Sunlight ON to see the cascade effect
• Turn Sunlight OFF and observe what happens
• Notice how Oxygen is a byproduct we breathe!
• See how ATP and NADPH connect the two stages

quiz.question: What are the three main inputs of photosynthesis?
What gas is released as a byproduct of photosynthesis?
What is the main product (food) that plants make?

teacherNotes: This model simplifies photosynthesis for middle school understanding.
Key concepts: energy transformation, inputs/outputs, cycles
Students can experiment with turning sunlight on/off to see effects
Extension: Compare to cellular respiration (reverse process)
